Male is the total number of male pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade as in a previous year, expressed as a percentage of the total male enrollment in the specified grade. LO.TIMSS.SCI4.INT.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study
LO.TIMSS.SCI4.INT.name: TIMSS: Fourth grade students reaching the intermediate international benchmark of science achievement (%)
LO.TIMSS.SCI4.INT.sourceNote: TIMSS: Fourth grade students reaching the intermediate international benchmark of science achievement (%) is the share of 4th grade students scoring at least 475 on the science assessment. Students reaching this benchmark have basic knowledge and understanding of practical situations in the sciences. Students recognize some basic information related to characteristics of living things, their reproduction and life cycles, and their interactions with the environment, and show some understanding of human biology and health. They also show some knowledge of properties of matter and light, electricity and energy, and forces and motion. Students know some basic facts about the solar system and show an initial understanding of Earth’s physical characteristics and resources. They demonstrate ability to interpret information in pictorial diagrams and apply factual knowledge to practical situations.

HH.MICS.OOST.L.Q5.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.OOST.L.Q5.name: MICS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry. Quintile 5
HH.MICS.OOST.L.Q5.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry. Quintile 5 is defined as the proportion of quintile 5 out-of-school children who are currently out of school but are expected to enter the education system later than they should. It is calculated based on UNESCO's methodology as the proportion leftover from those estimated as never in school, expressed as a percent of the proportion out-of-school for children younger than the age with the highest attendance rate.

LO.PASEC.FRE5.FE.sourceNote: PASEC: Mean performance on the French language scale (100 points) for 5th grade students, female is the average score on the 100 point French language scale for female 5th grade students. Note: Average differences are only significant between males and females in Benin, Burkina Faso, and Burundi. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

SE.PRM.EPCR.MA.ZS.name: Expected primary completion rate, male (% of population at theoretical entrance age)
SE.PRM.EPCR.MA.ZS.sourceNote: Expected primary completion rate. Male is the total number of new male entrants to the first grade of primary in a given year, regardless of age, who are expected to reach the last grade of primary education, regardless of repetition, expressed as a percentage of the male population at the official entrance age to primary education in the same year. It is calculated by multiplying the gross intake ratio to the first grade of primary education by the survival rate to the last grade of primary. This indicator is also known as "Expected gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary. Male."

LO.PIRLS.REA.INT.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Progress in International Reading Literacy Study (PIRLS)
LO.PIRLS.REA.INT.name: PIRLS: Fourth grade students reaching the intermediate international benchmark in reading achievement (%)
LO.PIRLS.REA.INT.sourceNote: Fourth grade students reaching the intermediate international benchmark in reading achievement (%) is the share of fourth grade students scoring at least 475 on the reading assessment. When reading Literary Texts, students at the intermediate benchmarking level can A) Retrieve and reproduce explicitly stated actions, events, and feelings, B) Make straightforward inferences about the attributes, feelings, and motivations of main characters, C) Interpret obvious reasons and causes and give simple explanations, and D) Begin to recognize language features and style. When reading Informational Texts, students at the informational level can A) Locate and reproduce two or three pieces of information from within the text, and B) Use subheadings, text boxes, and illustrations to locate parts of the text. For further information on benchmarking levels, please visit the PIRLS website.

UIS.T.4.GPV.F.name: Teaching staff in post-secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. General programmes. Female
UIS.T.4.GPV.F.sourceNote: Teaching staff in post-secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. General programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in general programmes in public and private post-secondary education institutions (ISCED 4). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

BAR.POP.3034.sourceNote: Population in thousands, 30-34, total is the total population of 30-34 year olds in thousands estimated by Barro-Lee.

SE.TER.TCHR.FE.ZS.name: Tertiary education, teachers (% female)
SE.TER.TCHR.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Tertiary is the number of female teachers at the tertiary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the tertiary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

UIS.SAP.4.M.name: School age population.  Post-secondary.  Male
UIS.SAP.4.M.sourceNote: School age population. Post-secondary. Male is the male population of the age-group theoretically corresponding to post-secondary education as indicated by theoretical entrance age and duration.

UIS.SAP.4.F.name: School age population.  Post-secondary.  Female
UIS.SAP.4.F.sourceNote: School age population. Post-secondary. Female is the female population of the age-group theoretically corresponding to post-secondary education as indicated by theoretical entrance age and duration.

UIS.XNATURCP.1.FDPUB.FNS.name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in primary education. All personnel salaries
UIS.XNATURCP.1.FDPUB.FNS.sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in primary education. All personnel salaries is the percentage of public current expenditures on primary education devoted to salaries.

MYS.MEA.YSCH.6569.MA.name: mean years of schooling, 65-69, male
MYS.MEA.YSCH.6569.MA.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 65-69, male is the mean years of schooling of the male population age 65-69.

SP.POP.AG16.TO.UN.name: Population, aged 16, total
SP.POP.AG16.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 16, total refers to the total population at the specified age.

MYS.PROP.1544.NED.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.1544.NED.FE.name: proportion, 15-44, female, no education
MYS.PROP.1544.NED.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 15-44, female, no education is the proportion of the female population age 15-44 with no education.

HH.MICS.OOST.X.F.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.OOST.X.F.name: MICS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school. Female
HH.MICS.OOST.X.F.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school. Female is the percentage of female out-of-school primary-school-age children who have never attended school and are not likely to enter school in the future. Since no survey can say definitively that a school-age person will never attend school, this is a probabilistic indicator. The indicator is based on UNESCO’s methodology, which estimates the proportion of children who will never attend school as the proportion of out of school for the age group with the lowest proportion of out-of-school children. This methodology assumes no dropout before the age at which enrolment rates peak, and no late entry after the age with peak enrolment.

MYS.PROP.4549.SEC.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.4549.SEC.FE.name: proportion, 45-49, female, secondary
MYS.PROP.4549.SEC.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 45-49, female, secondary is the proportion of the female population age 45-49 with secondary education.

UIS.SR.1.G4.GPI.name: Gender parity index for survival rate to grade 4
UIS.SR.1.G4.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for survival rate to grade 4 is the ratio of female survival rate to grade 4 to the male survival rate to grade 4. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

UIS.E.56.Fuk2.name: Enrolment in general programmes. Tertiary. Total
UIS.E.56.Fuk2.sourceNote: Enrolment in general programmes. Tertiary. Total is the total number of students enrolled in tertiary general programmes.

UIS.AFR.PBR.1.G1.PU.MATH.name: Africa Dataset: Pupil/textbook ratio. Mathematics. Primary. Grade 1. Public
UIS.AFR.PBR.1.G1.PU.MATH.sourceNote: Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

SP.POP.AG10.MA.UN.name: Population, aged 10, male
SP.POP.AG10.MA.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 10, male refers to the male population at the specified age.

HH.MICS.OOST.X.M.name: MICS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school. Male
HH.MICS.OOST.X.M.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school. Male is the percentage of male out-of-school primary-school-age children who have never attended school and are not likely to enter school in the future. Since no survey can say definitively that a school-age person will never attend school, this is a probabilistic indicator. The indicator is based on UNESCO’s methodology, which estimates the proportion of children who will never attend school as the proportion of out of school for the age group with the lowest proportion of out-of-school children. This methodology assumes no dropout before the age at which enrolment rates peak, and no late entry after the age with peak enrolment.

HH.MICS.OOST.X.U.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school. Urban is the percentage of urban out-of-school primary-school-age children who have never attended school and are not likely to enter school in the future. HH.MICS.OOST.X.R.name: MICS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school. Rural
HH.MICS.OOST.X.R.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school. Rural is the percentage of rural out-of-school primary-school-age children who have never attended school and are not likely to enter school in the future. Since no survey can say definitively that a school-age person will never attend school, this is a probabilistic indicator. This methodology assumes no dropout before the age at which enrolment rates peak, and no late entry after the age with peak enrolment.

UIS.REPR.1.G2.M.name: Repetition rate in primary. Grade 2. Male
UIS.REPR.1.G2.M.sourceNote: Repetition rate in primary. Grade 2. Male is the proportion of male pupils from a cohort enrolled in a given grade at a given school year who study in the same grade in the following school year.

BAR.POP.25UP.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.POP.25UP.name: population in thousands (age 15+), 25+, total
BAR.POP.25UP.sourceNote: Population in thousands, 25+, total is the total population over age 25 in thousands estimated by Barro-Lee.

SE.XPD.SECO.PC.ZS.name: Expenditure per student, secondary (% of GDP per capita)
SE.XPD.SECO.PC.ZS.sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. Secondary is the total public expenditure per student in secondary education as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).

SP.POP.0612.FE.UN.name: Population, aged 6-12, female
SP.POP.0612.FE.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 6-12, female is the total number of females age 6-12.

HH.DHS.SCR.Q1.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.SCR.Q1.name: DHS: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 1
HH.DHS.SCR.Q1.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 1 is the total number of quintile 1 students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of quintile 1 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 1 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

LO.PISA.REA.sourceOrganization: OECD Programme for International Student Assessment
LO.PISA.REA.name: PISA:Mean performance on the reading scale
LO.PISA.REA.sourceNote: PISA: Mean performance on the reading scale is the average score of 15-year-old students on combined reading literacy scale.

SE.SEC.ENRL.TC.ZS.sourceNote: Pupil-teacher ratio. Secondary is the number of pupils enrolled in secondary school divided by the number of secondary school teachers.

UIS.AFR.TRNTP.1.PU.T.name: Africa Dataset: Newly recruited teachers. % trained. Primary. Public. Total
UIS.AFR.TRNTP.1.PU.T.sourceNote: Share of newly recruited public primary school teachers who have been trained. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

SP.POP.1018.MA.UN.name: Population, aged 10-18, male
SP.POP.1018.MA.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 10-18, male is the total number of males age 10-18.

BAR.SCHL.2024.name: average years of total schooling, 20-24, total
BAR.SCHL.2024.sourceNote: Average years of total schooling, 20-24, total is the average years of education completed among people age 20-24.

UIS.E.3.V.PU.name: Enrolment in upper secondary. Public. Technical/vocational programmes. Total
UIS.E.3.V.PU.sourceNote: Enrolment in upper secondary. Public. Technical/vocational programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in technical/vocational programmes at public upper secondary education institutions.

BAR.PRM.SCHL.7074.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.PRM.SCHL.7074.name: average years of primary schooling, 70-74, total
BAR.PRM.SCHL.7074.sourceNote: Average years of primary schooling, 70-74, total is the average years of primary education completed among people age 70-74.

LO.TIMSS.SCI8.ADV.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)
LO.TIMSS.SCI8.ADV.name: TIMSS:Eighth grade students reaching the advanced international benchmark of science achievement (%)
LO.TIMSS.SCI8.ADV.sourceNote: TIMSS: Eighth grade students reaching the advanced international benchmark of science achievement (%)

SE.SEC.AGES.name: Secondary school starting age (years)
SE.SEC.AGES.sourceNote: Entrance age of 2A lower secondary is the age at which students would enter lower secondary education, assuming they had started at the official entrance age for the lowest level of education, had studied full-time throughout and had progressed through the system without repeating or skipping a grade.

SP.POP.AG19.FE.UN.name: Population, aged 19, female
SP.POP.AG19.FE.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 19, female refers to the female population at the specified age.

LO.TIMSS.MAT8.BL.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study
LO.TIMSS.MAT8.BL.name: TIMSS: Eighth grade students who did not reach the low international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%)
LO.TIMSS.MAT8.BL.sourceNote: TIMSS: Eighth grade students who did not reach the low international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%) is the share of 8th grade students scoring below 400 on the mathematics assessment. This indicator is calculated by subtracting the share of students reaching the low international benchmark from 100.

UIS.PRP.2.V.name: Percentage of private enrolment.  Lower secondary. Technical/vocational programmes
UIS.PRP.2.V.sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Lower secondary. Technical/vocational programmes is the enrolment in private lower secondary technical/vocational programmes expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in lower secondary technical/vocational programmes. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.

UIS.XGDP.234.FDINSTADM.FFD.name: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary
UIS.XGDP.234.FDINSTADM.FFD.sourceNote: Total expenditure on educational institutions and administration as a % of GDP. All sources. Secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary is the expenditure coming from public, private and international sources spent on secondary and post-secondary non-tertiary education expressed as a % of GDP.

UIS.AFR.SCHBSP.1.PU.WOTOIL.name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools without toilets. Primary. Public
UIS.AFR.SCHBSP.1.PU.WOTOIL.sourceNote: Share of primary schools without a pit latrine, flush toilet, pour-flush toilet or a composting toilet. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

MYS.POP.25UP.TER.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.25UP.TER.MF.name: population in thousand, 25+, total, tertiary
MYS.POP.25UP.TER.MF.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 25+, total, tertiary is the total number of people over age 25 (in thousands) with tertiary education.

UIS.R.23.GPV.G4.F.name: Repeaters in secondary. Grade 4. Female
UIS.R.23.GPV.G4.F.sourceNote: Repeaters in secondary. Grade 4. Female is the number of female pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade for a second (or further) year.

MYS.POP.25UP.TER.MA.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.25UP.TER.MA.name: population in thousand, 25+, male, tertiary
MYS.POP.25UP.TER.MA.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 25+, male, tertiary is the total number of males over age 25 (in thousands) with tertiary education.

LO.LLECE.MAT6.HIG.sourceOrganization: Latin American Laboratory for Assessment of the Quality of Education (LLECE)
LO.LLECE.MAT6.HIG.name: LLECE: 6th grade students at the highest level of proficiency on the mathematics scale (%), total
LO.LLECE.MAT6.HIG.sourceNote: 6th grade students at the highest level of proficiency on the mathematics scale (%), total

UIS.SAP.1.G1.name: School age population.  Official entrance age.  Total
UIS.SAP.1.G1.sourceNote: School age population. Official entrance age. Total is the population of the age-group theoretically corresponding to the official entrance age.

MYS.PROP.3034.NED.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.3034.NED.FE.name: proportion, 30 - 34, female, no education
MYS.PROP.3034.NED.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 30-34, female, no education is the proportion of the female population age 30-34 with no education.

BAR.PRM.SCHL.15UP.FE.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.PRM.SCHL.15UP.FE.name: average years of primary schooling, 15+, female
BAR.PRM.SCHL.15UP.FE.sourceNote: Average years of primary schooling, 15+, female is the average years of primary education completed among females over age 15.

SP.POP.1215.TO.UN.name: Population, aged 12-15, total
SP.POP.1215.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 12-15, total is the total population age 12-15.

SE.ADT.LITR.FE.ZS.name: Literacy rate, adult female (% of females ages 15 and above)
SE.ADT.LITR.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Adult (15+) literacy rate (%). Female is the percentage of females age 15 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement on their everyday life. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of female literates aged 15 years and over by the corresponding age group population and multiplying the result by 100.

MYS.POP.4564.NED.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.4564.NED.FE.name: population in thousand, 45-64, female, no education
MYS.POP.4564.NED.FE.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 45-64, female, no education is the total number of females age 45-64 (in thousands) with no education.

UIS.FOSEP.56.F200.F.name: Percentage of female tertiary enrolments (ISCED 5 and 6) in humanities and arts
UIS.FOSEP.56.F200.F.sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary enrolments (ISCED 5 and 6) in humanities and arts is the percentage of all female tertiary students who are enrolled in humanities and arts programmes.

MYS.PROP.3539.SEC.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.3539.SEC.FE.name: proportion, 35-39, female, secondary
MYS.PROP.3539.SEC.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 35-39, female, secondary is the proportion of the female population age 35-39 with secondary education.

SP.POP.1418.MA.UN.name: Population, aged 14-18, male
SP.POP.1418.MA.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 14-18, male is the total number of males age 14-18.

MYS.PROP.15UP.NED.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.15UP.NED.FE.name: proportion, 15+, female, no education
MYS.PROP.15UP.NED.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 15+, female, no education is the proportion of the female population over age 15 with no education.

UIS.AFR.SCHBSP.1.PU.WSTOIL.name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools with single-sex toilets. Primary. Public
UIS.AFR.SCHBSP.1.PU.WSTOIL.sourceNote: Share of primary schools with separate girls and boys toilets or single-sex educational institutions with toilets. Schools are counted as having toilets if they have a pit latrine, an improved pit latrine, a flush toilet, a pour-flush toilet or a composting toilet. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

BAR.PRM.ICMP.15UP.FE.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.PRM.ICMP.15UP.FE.ZS.name: Barro-Lee: Percentage of female population age 15+ with primary schooling. Total (Incomplete and Completed Primary)
BAR.PRM.ICMP.15UP.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of female population age 15+ with primary schooling. Total (Incomplete and Completed Primary)

SE.TER.TCHR.name: Tertiary education, teachers
SE.TER.TCHR.sourceNote: Teaching staff in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in public and private tertiary education institutions (ISCED 5 & 6). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

NY.GNP.PCAP.CD.sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.
NY.GNP.PCAP.CD.name: GNI per capita, Atlas method (current US$)
NY.GNP.PCAP.CD.sourceNote: GNI per capita (formerly GNP per capita) is the gross national income, converted to U.S. dollars using the World Bank Atlas method, divided by the midyear population. GNI is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. GNI, calculated in national currency, is usually converted to U.S. dollars at official exchange rates for comparisons across economies, although an alternative rate is used when the official exchange rate is judged to diverge by an exceptionally large margin from the rate actually applied in international transactions. To smooth fluctuations in prices and exchange rates, a special Atlas method of conversion is used by the World Bank. This applies a conversion factor that averages the exchange rate for a given year and the two preceding years, adjusted for differences in rates of inflation between the country, and through 2000, the G-5 countries (France, Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States). From 2001, these countries include the Euro area, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.

SP.POP.0014.MA.IN.sourceOrganization: The United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.
SP.POP.0014.MA.IN.name: Population ages 0-14, male
SP.POP.0014.MA.IN.sourceNote: Population, age 0-14, male is the male population between the ages of 0 and 14.

SE.PRM.TCAQ.MA.ZS.name: Trained teachers in primary education, male (% of male teachers)
SE.PRM.TCAQ.MA.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Primary. Male is the number of male teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the primary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of male teachers at the primary level.

SE.ADT.1524.LT.ZS.name: Literacy rate, youth total (% of people ages 15-24)
SE.ADT.1524.LT.ZS.sourceNote: Youth (15-24) literacy rate (%). Total is the number of people age 15 to 24 years who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement on their everyday life, divided by the population in that age group. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations.

BAR.TER.CMPT.4549.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of population age 45-49 with tertiary schooling. Completed Tertiary

BAR.TER.ICMP.7074.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of female population age 70-74 with tertiary schooling. Total (Incomplete and Completed Tertiary)

SP.POP.1117.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 11-17, total is the total population age 11-17.

UIS.REPR.1.G6.M.name: Repetition rate in primary. Grade 6. Male
UIS.REPR.1.G6.M.sourceNote: Repetition rate in primary. Grade 6. Male is the proportion of male pupils from a cohort enrolled in a given grade at a given school year who study in the same grade in the following school year.

MYS.PROP.1519.PRI.MA.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.1519.PRI.MA.name: proportion, 15-19, male, primary
MYS.PROP.1519.PRI.MA.sourceNote: Proportion, 15-19, male, primary is the proportion of the male population age 15-19 with primary education.

MYS.PROP.1519.PRI.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.1519.PRI.MF.name: proportion, 15-19, total, primary
MYS.PROP.1519.PRI.MF.sourceNote: Proportion, 15-19, total, primary is the proportion of the population age 15-19 with primary education.

HH.DHS.OOS.1.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOS.1.name: DHS: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary
HH.DHS.OOS.1.sourceNote: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary is the number of children in the official primary school age range who are not attending primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of children of the official primary school age range. By definition, children in the official primary-age range, who are attending pre-primary education, are considered out-of-school. The sum of the net primary attendance rate and the proportion out of school do not add to 100 percent because the net primary attendance rate does not count students who are in secondary.

UIS.GER.3.GPI.name: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio.  Upper secondary.  All programmes
UIS.GER.3.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio. Upper secondary. All programmes is the ratio of female gross enrolment ratio for upper secondary (All programmes) to the male gross enrolment ratio for upper secondary (All programmes). It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q4.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q4.name: DHS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 4
HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q4.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 4 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 4 population of the given age group.

HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q5.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q5.name: DHS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 5
HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q5.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 5 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 5 population of the given age group.

HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q2.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q2.name: DHS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 2
HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q2.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 2 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 2 population of the given age group.

HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q3.name: DHS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 3
HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q3.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 3 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 3 population of the given age group.

SP.POP.0609.FE.UN.name: Population, aged 6- 9,female
SP.POP.0609.FE.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 6-9, female is the total number of females age 6-9.

HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q1.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q1.name: DHS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 1
HH.DHS.YRS.1519.Q1.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 1 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 1 population of the given age group.

UIS.E.1.G7.F.name: Enrolment in primary. Grade 7.  Female
UIS.E.1.G7.F.sourceNote: Enrolment in primary. Grade 7. Female is the total number of female students enrolled in Grade 7 of primary education.

UIS.TE_100000.56.M.name: Number of students in tertiary education per 100,000 inhabitants. Male
UIS.TE_100000.56.M.sourceNote: Number of students in tertiary education per 100,000 inhabitants. Male is the number of male students enrolled in tertiary education in a given academic year per 100,000 inhabitants. It is calculated by dividing the total number of male students enrolled in tertiary education in a given academic year by the country’s population and multiplying the result by 100,000.

SE.SEC.PRIV.ZS.name: School enrollment, secondary, private (% of total secondary)
SE.SEC.PRIV.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Secondary is the enrolment in private secondary schools expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in secondary schools. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.

UIS.E.1.G5.F.name: Enrolment in primary. Grade 5.  Female
UIS.E.1.G5.F.sourceNote: Enrolment in primary. Grade 5. Female is the total number of female students enrolled in Grade 5 of primary education.

UIS.thDur.0.name: Duration of pre-primary
UIS.thDur.0.sourceNote: Duration of pre-primary is the number of grades (years) in pre-primary education.

MYS.POP.15UP.PRI.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.15UP.PRI.FE.name: population in thousand, 15+, female, primary
MYS.POP.15UP.PRI.FE.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 15+, female, primary is the total number of females over age 15 (in thousands) with primary education.

SP.POP.AG22.TO.UN.name: Population, aged 22, total
SP.POP.AG22.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 22, total refers to the total population at the specified age.

LO.PISA.SCI.HIG.sourceNote: PISA: Students at the highest level of proficiency on the science scale (%) is the percentage of students at Level 6 (above 707.93 score points) on the science scale.

SP.SEC.UTOT.MA.IN.sourceNote: School age population. Upper secondary. Male is the male population of the age-group theoretically corresponding to upper secondary education as indicated by theoretical entrance age and duration.

LO.LLECE.SCI6.LOW.sourceOrganization: Latin American Laboratory for Assessment of the Quality of Education (LLECE)

BAR.TER.SCHL.2024.name: average years of tertiary schooling, 20-24, total
BAR.TER.SCHL.2024.sourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 20-24, total is the average years of tertiary education completed among people age 20-24.

MYS.MEA.YSCH.65UP.FE.name: mean years of schooling, 65+, female
MYS.MEA.YSCH.65UP.FE.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 65+, female is the mean years of schooling of the female population over age 65.

MYS.PROP.80UP.TER.FE.name: proportion, 80+, female, tertiary

UIS.T.5.B.F.name: Teaching staff in 5B tertiary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female
UIS.T.5.B.F.sourceNote: Teaching staff in 5B tertiary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in public and private ISCED 5B tertiary education institutions. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

MYS.POP.4044.SEC.FE.name: population in thousand, 40-44, female, secondary

MYS.MEA.YSCH.2024.MA.name: mean years of schooling, 20 - 24, male
MYS.MEA.YSCH.2024.MA.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 20 - 24, male is the mean years of schooling of the male population age 20-24.

LO.PISA.REA.LOW.FE.sourceOrganization: OECD Programme for International Student Assessment
LO.PISA.REA.LOW.FE.name: PISA:Students at the lowest level of proficiency on the reading scale (%), female
LO.PISA.REA.LOW.FE.sourceNote: PISA: Students at the lowest level of proficiency on the reading scale (%), female is the percentage of female students below Level 1b (less than 262.04 score points) on the reading scale.

MYS.POP.6064.SEC.MA.name: population in thousand, 60-64, male, secondary

MYS.MEA.YSCH.2024.MF.name: mean years of schooling, 20 - 24, total
MYS.MEA.YSCH.2024.MF.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 20 - 24, total is the mean years of schooling of the population age 20-24.

MYS.POP.4044.NED.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.4044.NED.MF.name: population in thousand, 40-44, total, no education
MYS.POP.4044.NED.MF.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 40-44, total, no education is the total number of people age 40-44 (in thousands) with no education.

MYS.POP.5054.SEC.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.5054.SEC.MF.name: population in thousand, 50-54, total, secondary
MYS.POP.5054.SEC.MF.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 50-54, total, secondary is the total number of people age 50-54 (in thousands) with secondary education.

UIS.AFR.CS.SG.1.G2.PU.name: Africa Dataset: Average class size. Single grade classes. Grade 2. Primary. Public
UIS.AFR.CS.SG.1.G2.PU.sourceNote: Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

SL.TLF.SECO.MA.ZS.sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.
SL.TLF.SECO.MA.ZS.name: Labor force with secondary education, male (% of male labor force)
SL.TLF.SECO.MA.ZS.sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.

UIS.DR.1.G4.F.name: Drop-out rate. Primary. Grade 4. Female
UIS.DR.1.G4.F.sourceNote: Drop-out rate. Primary. Grade 4. Female is the proportion of female pupils from a cohort enrolled in primary education in a given school year who are no longer enrolled in the following school year.

SP.POP.AG12.FE.UN.name: Population, aged 12, female
SP.POP.AG12.FE.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 12, female refers to the female population at the specified age.

UIS.E.23.GPV.PU.name: Enrolment in total secondary. Public. General programmes. Total
UIS.E.23.GPV.PU.sourceNote: Enrolment in total secondary. Public. General programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in general programmes in public secondary education institutions.

LO.PASEC.FRE5.HIG.MA.sourceOrganization: Programme d'Analyse des Systèmes Educatifs de la CONFEMEN/Program on the Analysis of Education Systems
LO.PASEC.FRE5.HIG.MA.name: PASEC: 5th grade students above the Knowledge Base Rate on the French language scale (above 40% of answers correct) (%), male
LO.PASEC.FRE5.HIG.MA.sourceNote: Indicator is the share of male students who score above the Knowledge Base Rate, which is the proportion of pupils who achieve a minimum learning goal, based on the programs of the level selected, appropriate to the scale of the tests used.

UIS.G.56.F200.dcount.F.name: Graduates in humanities and arts. Tertiary. Female
UIS.G.56.F200.dcount.F.sourceNote: Graduates in humanities and arts. Tertiary. Female is the total number of female tertiary graduates from humanities and arts programs.

BAR.SCHL.3034.FE.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.SCHL.3034.FE.name: average years of total schooling, 30-34, female
BAR.SCHL.3034.FE.sourceNote: Average years of total schooling, 30-34, female is the average years of education completed among females age 30-34.

HH.MICS.PCR.U.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.PCR.U.name: MICS: Primary completion rate. Urban
HH.MICS.PCR.U.sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Urban is the total number of urban students of any age in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of urban repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of urban children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of primary school.

SE.PRM.TCHR.FE.name: Teaching staff in primary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female
SE.PRM.TCHR.FE.sourceNote: Teaching staff in primary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in public and private primary education institutions. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

HH.MICS.PCR.R.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.PCR.R.name: MICS: Primary completion rate. Rural
HH.MICS.PCR.R.sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Rural is the total number of rural students of any age in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of rural repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of rural children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of primary school.

SE.TER.GRAD.FE.AG.ZS.name: Female share of graduates in agriculture (%, tertiary)
SE.TER.GRAD.FE.AG.ZS.sourceNote: Female share of graduates in agriculture (%, tertiary)

UIS.LR.AG65.M.name: Elderly (65+) literacy rate (%). Male
UIS.LR.AG65.M.sourceNote: Elderly (65+) literacy rate (%). Male is the percentage of males age 65 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement on their everyday life. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of male literates aged 65 years and over by the corresponding age group population and multiplying the result by 100.

BAR.TER.SCHL.2529.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.TER.SCHL.2529.name: average years of tertiary schooling, 25-29, total
BAR.TER.SCHL.2529.sourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 25-29, total is the average years of tertiary education completed among people age 25-29.

MYS.MEA.YSCH.4044.FE.name: mean years of schooling, 40-44, female
MYS.MEA.YSCH.4044.FE.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 40-44, female is the mean years of schooling of the female population age 40-44.

MYS.PROP.2529.PRI.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.2529.PRI.FE.name: proportion, 25 - 29, female, primary
MYS.PROP.2529.PRI.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 25-29, female, primary is the proportion of the female population age 25-29 with primary education.

BAR.SCHL.15UP.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.SCHL.15UP.name: average years of total schooling, 15+, total
BAR.SCHL.15UP.sourceNote: Average years of total schooling, 15+, total is the average years of education completed among people over age 15.

LO.LLECE.MAT3.HIG.sourceOrganization: Latin American Laboratory for Assessment of the Quality of Education (LLECE)
LO.LLECE.MAT3.HIG.name: LLECE: 3rd grade students at the highest level of proficiency on the mathematics scale (%), total
LO.LLECE.MAT3.HIG.sourceNote: 3rd grade students at the highest level of proficiency on the mathematics scale (%), total

HH.MICS.PCR.M.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.PCR.M.name: MICS: Primary completion rate. Male
HH.MICS.PCR.M.sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Male is the total number of male students of any age in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of male repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of male children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of primary school.

MYS.MEA.YSCH.3034.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.MEA.YSCH.3034.FE.name: mean years of schooling, 30 - 34, female
MYS.MEA.YSCH.3034.FE.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 30 - 34, female is the mean years of schooling of the female population age 30-34.

UIS.XPUBP.UK.name: Educational expenditure not allocated by level as % of total educational expenditure
UIS.XPUBP.UK.sourceNote: Educational expenditure not allocated by level as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure that is not allocated by educational level. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.

UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G8.name: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 8. Total
UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G8.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 8. Total is the total number of pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade as in a previous year, expressed as a percentage of the total enrollment in the specified grade. It is calculated by dividing the number of pupils repeating a given grade in a given school year by the number of pupils enrolled in the same grade in the same school year and multiplying by 100.

SE.SEC.ENRL.MA.VO.ZS.name: Vocational and Technical enrollment (% of total secondary enrollment), male
SE.SEC.ENRL.MA.VO.ZS.sourceNote: Technical/vocational enrolment in secondary (ISCED 2 and 3) as % of total secondary enrolment (ISCED 2 and 3), male is the percentage of all male lower and upper secondary students enrolled in technical/vocational education programs including teacher training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of male students who are enrolled in lower and upper secondary education.

UIS.FOSEP.56.F300.F.name: Percentage of female tertiary enrolments (ISCED 5 and 6) in social sciences, business and law
UIS.FOSEP.56.F300.F.sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary enrolments (ISCED 5 and 6) in social sciences, business and law is the percentage of all female tertiary students who are enrolled in social sciences, business and law programmes.

NY.GDP.PCAP.KD.sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.
NY.GDP.PCAP.KD.name: GDP per capita (constant 2005 US$)
NY.GDP.PCAP.KD.sourceNote: GDP per capita is gross domestic product divided by midyear population. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2005 U.S. dollars.

SE.PRM.PRSL.MA.ZS.name: Persistence to last grade of primary, male (% of cohort)
SE.PRM.PRSL.MA.ZS.sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of primary. Male is the share of male children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach the last grade of primary. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.

LO.SACMEQ.MAT.LOW.MA.sourceOrganization: Southern and Eastern Africa Consortium for Monitoring Educational Quality (SACMEQ) Data Archive, www.sacmeq.org
LO.SACMEQ.MAT.LOW.MA.name: SACMEQ:Students at the lowest level of proficiency on the mathematics scale (%), male
LO.SACMEQ.MAT.LOW.MA.sourceNote: Students at the lowest level of proficiency on the mathematics scale (%), male

UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G6.name: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 6. Total
UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G6.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 6. Total is the total number of pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade as in a previous year, expressed as a percentage of the total enrollment in the specified grade. It is calculated by dividing the number of pupils repeating a given grade in a given school year by the number of pupils enrolled in the same grade in the same school year and multiplying by 100.

LO.TIMSS.SCI8.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)
LO.TIMSS.SCI8.name: TIMSS:Mean performance on the science scale  for eighth grade students, total
LO.TIMSS.SCI8.sourceNote: TIMSS: Mean performance on the science scale for eighth grade students, total

HH.DHS.OOST.DO.Q5.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.Q5.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Quintile 5
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.Q5.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Quintile 5 is the proportion of quintile 5 out-of-school children who were enrolled in school and dropped out. It is calculated as the proportion of children not classified as never-in-school expressed as a percent of the proportion of out-of-school children older than the age with the highest attendance rate.

MYS.MEA.YSCH.4549.MA.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.MEA.YSCH.4549.MA.name: mean years of schooling, 45-49, male
MYS.MEA.YSCH.4549.MA.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 45-49, male is the mean years of schooling of the male population age 45-49.

HH.DHS.OOST.DO.Q1.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.Q1.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Quintile 1
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.Q1.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Quintile 1 is the proportion of quintile 1 out-of-school children who were enrolled in school and dropped out. It is calculated as the proportion of children not classified as never-in-school expressed as a percent of the proportion of out-of-school children older than the age with the highest attendance rate.

MYS.PROP.7579.PRI.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.7579.PRI.FE.name: proportion, 75-79, female, primary
MYS.PROP.7579.PRI.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 75-79, female, primary is the proportion of the female population age 75-79 with primary education.

HH.DHS.OOST.DO.Q2.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.Q2.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Quintile 2
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.Q2.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Quintile 2 is the proportion of quintile 2 out-of-school children who were enrolled in school and dropped out. It is calculated as the proportion of children not classified as never-in-school expressed as a percent of the proportion of out-of-school children older than the age with the highest attendance rate.

MYS.PROP.15UP.PRI.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.15UP.PRI.MF.name: proportion, 15+, total, primary
MYS.PROP.15UP.PRI.MF.sourceNote: Proportion, 15+, total, primary is the proportion of the population over age 15 with primary education.

MYS.PROP.15UP.PRI.MA.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.15UP.PRI.MA.name: proportion, 15+, male, primary
MYS.PROP.15UP.PRI.MA.sourceNote: Proportion, 15+, male, primary is the proportion of the male population over age 15 with primary education.

SP.SEC.TOTL.IN.name: Population, secondary, total
SP.SEC.TOTL.IN.sourceNote: School age population. Secondary. Total is the population of the age-group theoretically corresponding to secondary education as indicated by theoretical entrance age and duration.

MYS.PROP.6064.PRI.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.6064.PRI.MF.name: proportion, 60-64, total, primary
MYS.PROP.6064.PRI.MF.sourceNote: Proportion, 60-64, total, primary is the proportion of the population age 60-64 with primary education.

LO.PISA.SCI.MA.sourceOrganization: OECD Programme for International Student Assessment
LO.PISA.SCI.MA.name: PISA:Mean performance on the science scale, male
LO.PISA.SCI.MA.sourceNote: PISA: Mean performance on the science scale, male is the average score of 15-year-old male students on science literacy scale.

UIS.G.56.F600.dcount.name: Graduates in agriculture. Tertiary. Total
UIS.G.56.F600.dcount.sourceNote: Graduates in agriculture. Tertiary. Total is the total number of tertiary graduates from agriculture programs.

MYS.PROP.6064.PRI.MA.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.6064.PRI.MA.name: proportion, 60-64, male, primary
MYS.PROP.6064.PRI.MA.sourceNote: Proportion, 60-64, male, primary is the proportion of the male population age 60-64 with primary education.

BAR.POP.2529.FE.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.POP.2529.FE.name: population in thousands (age 15+), 25-29, female
BAR.POP.2529.FE.sourceNote: Population in thousands, 25-29, female is the female population of 25-29 year olds in thousands estimated by Barro-Lee.

HH.DHS.SCR.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.SCR.name: DHS: Secondary completion rate
HH.DHS.SCR.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate is the total number of students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

SP.POP.1318.TO.UN.name: Population, aged 13-18, total
SP.POP.1318.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 13-18, total is the total population age 13-18.

UIS.NER.0.GPI.name: Gender parity index for net enrolment rate.  Pre-primary
UIS.NER.0.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for net enrolment rate. Pre-primary is the ratio of female net enrolment rate for pre-primary to the male net enrolment rate for pre-primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

SP.POP.AG19.MA.UN.name: Population, aged 19, male
SP.POP.AG19.MA.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 19, male refers to the male population at the specified age.

BAR.PRM.CMPT.25UP.FE.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.PRM.CMPT.25UP.FE.ZS.name: Barro-Lee: Percentage of female population age 25+ with primary schooling. Completed Primary
BAR.PRM.CMPT.25UP.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of female population age 25+ with primary schooling. Completed Primary

UIS.E.56.F200.F.name: Enrolment in humanities and arts. Tertiary.  Female
UIS.E.56.F200.F.sourceNote: Enrolment in humanities and arts. Tertiary. Female is the total number of females enrolled in tertiary humanities and arts programs.

SE.PRE.NENR.MA.name: Net enrolment rate.  Pre-primary.  Male
SE.PRE.NENR.MA.sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Pre-primary. Male is the ratio of male children of the official pre-primary school age who are enrolled in pre-primary school to the male population of the official pre-primary school age.

SE.XPD.PRIM.PC.ZS.name: Expenditure per student, primary (% of GDP per capita)
SE.XPD.PRIM.PC.ZS.sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. Primary is the total public expenditure per student in primary education as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).

SP.SEC.UTOT.IN.name: Population, upper secondary, total
SP.SEC.UTOT.IN.sourceNote: School age population. Upper secondary. Total is the population of the age-group theoretically corresponding to upper secondary education as indicated by theoretical entrance age and duration.

UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G7.F.name: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 7. Female
UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G7.F.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 7. Female is the total number of female pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade as in a previous year, expressed as a percentage of the total female enrollment in the specified grade. It is calculated by dividing the number of female pupils repeating a given grade in a given school year by the number of female pupils enrolled in the same grade in the same school year and multiplying by 100.

UIS.DR.1.G6.M.name: Drop-out rate. Primary. Grade 6. Male
UIS.DR.1.G6.M.sourceNote: Drop-out rate. Primary. Grade 6. Male is the proportion of male pupils from a cohort enrolled in primary education in a given school year who are no longer enrolled in the following school year.

BAR.SEC.SCHL.4549.FE.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.SEC.SCHL.4549.FE.name: average years of secondary schooling, 45-49, female
BAR.SEC.SCHL.4549.FE.sourceNote: Average years of secondary schooling, 45-49, female is the average years of secondary education completed among females age 45-49.

HH.MICS.TR.12.F.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.TR.12.F.name: MICS: Transition rate. Primary to Secondary. Female
HH.MICS.TR.12.F.sourceNote: Transition rate. Primary to Secondary. Female is the proportion of female pupils in the last grade of primary who transition to the first grade of secondary the following school year.

BAR.SCHL.15UP.FE.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.SCHL.15UP.FE.name: average years of total schooling, 15+, female
BAR.SCHL.15UP.FE.sourceNote: Average years of total schooling, 15+, female is the average years of education completed among females over age 15.

MYS.PROP.1544.TER.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.1544.TER.FE.name: proportion, 15-44, female, tertiary
MYS.PROP.1544.TER.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 15-44, female, tertiary is the proportion of the female population age 15-44 with tertiary education.

HH.MICS.TR.12.M.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.TR.12.M.name: MICS: Transition rate. Primary to Secondary. Male
HH.MICS.TR.12.M.sourceNote: Transition rate. Primary to Secondary. Male is the proportion of male pupils in the last grade of primary who transition to the first grade of secondary the following school year.

UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G7.M.name: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 7. Male
UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G7.M.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 7. Male is the total number of male pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade as in a previous year, expressed as a percentage of the total male enrollment in the specified grade. It is calculated by dividing the number of male pupils repeating a given grade in a given school year by the male number of pupils enrolled in the same grade in the same school year and multiplying by 100.

BAR.NOED.25UP.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.NOED.25UP.ZS.name: Barro-Lee: Percentage of population age 25+ with no education
BAR.NOED.25UP.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of population age 25+ with no education

MYS.POP.15UP.NED.MA.name: population in thousand, 15+, male, no education
MYS.POP.15UP.NED.MA.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 15+, male, no education is the total number of males over age 15 (in thousands) with no education.

HH.MICS.TR.12.R.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.TR.12.R.name: MICS: Transition rate. Primary to Secondary. Rural
HH.MICS.TR.12.R.sourceNote: Transition rate. Primary to Secondary. Rural is the proportion of rural pupils in the last grade of primary who transition to the first grade of secondary the following school year.

LO.TIMSS.SCI4.LOW.sourceNote: TIMSS: Fourth grade students reaching the low international benchmark of science achievement (%)

MYS.POP.15UP.NED.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.15UP.NED.MF.name: population in thousand, 15+, total, no education

BAR.TER.CMPT.5054.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of population age 50-54 with tertiary schooling. Completed Tertiary

MYS.PROP.1564.TER.MA.name: proportion, 15-64, male, tertiary

LO.PIRLS.REA.FE.name: PIRLS:Mean performance on the reading scale, female

HH.DHS.OOST.DO.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out is the proportion of out-of-school children who were enrolled in school and dropped out. It is calculated as the proportion of children not classified as never-in-school expressed as a percent of the proportion of out-of-school children older than the age with the highest attendance rate.

SE.TER.GRAD.OT.ZS.name: Graduates in unknown or unspecified fields (% of total graduates, tertiary)
SE.TER.GRAD.OT.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in unspecified programmes is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied in unspecified programmes.

UIS.REPP.3.GPV.F.name: Percentage of repeaters in upper secondary. All grades. Female
UIS.REPP.3.GPV.F.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in upper secondary. All grades. It is calculated by dividing the sum of female repeaters in all grades of upper secondary education by the total female enrolment of upper secondary education and multiplying the result by 100.

HH.DHS.SCR.F.name: DHS: Secondary completion rate. Female

Female is the total number of female students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of female repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of female children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

SP.POP.AG07.TO.UN.name: Population, aged  7, total
SP.POP.AG07.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 7, total refers to the total population at the specified age.

MYS.PROP.2024.SEC.MA.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.2024.SEC.MA.name: proportion, 20 - 24, male, secondary
MYS.PROP.2024.SEC.MA.sourceNote: Proportion, 20-24, male, secondary is the proportion of the male population age 20-24 with secondary education.

HH.DHS.SCR.M.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.SCR.M.name: DHS: Secondary completion rate. Male
HH.DHS.SCR.M.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Male is the total number of male students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of male repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of male children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

SP.POP.1318.MA.UN.name: Population, aged 13-18, male
SP.POP.1318.MA.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 13-18, male is the total number of males age 13-18.

HH.MICS.OOS.1.M.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.OOS.1.M.name: MICS: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Male
HH.MICS.OOS.1.M.sourceNote: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Male is the number of male children in the official primary school age range who are not attending primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of male children of the official primary school age range. By definition, children in the official primary-age range, who are attending pre-primary education, are considered out-of-school. The sum of the net primary attendance rate and the proportion out of school do not add to 100 percent because the net primary attendance rate does not count students who are in secondary.

HH.MICS.OOS.1.R.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.OOS.1.R.name: MICS: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Rural
HH.MICS.OOS.1.R.sourceNote: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Rural is the number of rural children in the official primary school age range who are not attending primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of rural children of the official primary school age range. By definition, children in the official primary-age range, who are attending pre-primary education, are considered out-of-school. The sum of the net primary attendance rate and the proportion out of school do not add to 100 percent because the net primary attendance rate does not count students who are in secondary.

HH.DHS.SCR.R.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.SCR.R.name: DHS: Secondary completion rate. Rural
HH.DHS.SCR.R.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Rural is the total number of rural students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of rural repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of rural children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

HH.DHS.SCR.U.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.SCR.U.name: DHS: Secondary completion rate. Urban
HH.DHS.SCR.U.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Urban is the total number of urban students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of urban repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of urban children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

SE.ENR.TERT.FM.ZS.sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.
SE.ENR.TERT.FM.ZS.name: Ratio of female to male tertiary enrollment (%)
SE.ENR.TERT.FM.ZS.sourceNote: Ratio of female to male tertiary enrollment is the percentage of men to women enrolled at tertiary level in public and private schools.

HH.MICS.OOS.1.U.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.OOS.1.U.name: MICS: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Urban
HH.MICS.OOS.1.U.sourceNote: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Urban is the number of urban children in the official primary school age range who are not attending primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of urban children of the official primary school age range. By definition, children in the official primary-age range, who are attending pre-primary education, are considered out-of-school. The sum of the net primary attendance rate and the proportion out of school do not add to 100 percent because the net primary attendance rate does not count students who are in secondary.

HH.DHS.OOST.L.Q5.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.L.Q5.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry. Quintile 5
HH.DHS.OOST.L.Q5.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry. Quintile 5 is defined as the proportion of quintile 5 out-of-school children who are currently out of school but are expected to enter the education system later than they should. It is calculated based on UNESCO's methodology as the proportion leftover from those estimated as never in school, expressed as a percent of the proportion out-of-school for children younger than the age with the highest attendance rate.

SP.POP.1217.TO.UN.name: Population, aged 12-17, total
SP.POP.1217.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 12-17, total is the total population age 12-17.

SE.SEC.ENRR.LO.FE.name: Gross enrollment rate (%), lower secondary, female
SE.SEC.ENRR.LO.FE.sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Lower secondary. All programmes. Female is the total female enrollment in lower secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total female population of official lower secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.

UIS.E.0.AgI0.name: Pupils of the official school age.  Pre-primary.  Total
UIS.E.0.AgI0.sourceNote: Pupils of the official school age. Pre-primary. Total is the total number of pre-primary students who are of the official pre-primary school age. NOTE: These values are not ‘capped’ i.e. the values are not necessarily the numerators used to calculate the net enrolment rates (for cases that are capped). To obtain the numerator for the NER, you can simply multiply the SAP of a relevant level by its corresponding NER.

SE.ADT.LITR.MA.ZS.name: Literacy rate, adult male (% of males ages 15 and above)
SE.ADT.LITR.MA.ZS.sourceNote: Adult (15+) literacy rate (%). Male is the percentage of males age 15 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement on their everyday life. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of male literates aged 15 years and over by the corresponding age group population and multiplying the result by 100.

SP.POP.1115.TO.UN.name: Population, aged 11-15, total
SP.POP.1115.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 11-15, total is the total population age 11-15.

SE.TER.ENRL.FE.ZS.name: Girls enrollment share (%), tertiary
SE.TER.ENRL.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of female students. Total tertiary is the number of female students at the tertiary education level (ISCED 5 and 6) expressed as a percentage of the total number of students (male and female) at the tertiary education level in a given school year.

MYS.PROP.3034.SEC.MF.name: proportion, 30 - 34, total, secondary

UIS.SR.2.GPV.GLAST.GPI.name: Gender parity index for survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes)
UIS.SR.2.GPV.GLAST.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes) is the ratio of female to male vales for the indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G5.M.name: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 5. Male
UIS.REPP.23.GPV.G5.M.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. Grade 5. Male is the total number of male pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade as in a previous year, expressed as a percentage of the total male enrollment in the specified grade. It is calculated by dividing the number of male pupils repeating a given grade in a given school year by the male number of pupils enrolled in the same grade in the same school year and multiplying by 100.

LO.PASEC.FRE5.LO.MA.sourceOrganization: Programme d'Analyse des Systèmes Educatifs de la CONFEMEN/Program on the Analysis of Education Systems

LO.PASEC.FRE5.LO.MA.sourceNote: Indicator is for Failure Rate on the PASEC exam, which is less than the score a pupil could obtain by completing the PASEC test randomly.

SP.POP.1014.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 10-14, total is the total population age 10-14.

BAR.SEC.CMPT.15UP.FE.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

UIS.REPP.2.GPV.F.name: Percentage of repeaters in lower secondary. All grades. Female
UIS.REPP.2.GPV.F.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in lower secondary. All grades. Female is the number of female students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all female students enrolled in lower secondary school. It is calculated by dividing the sum of female repeaters in all grades of lower secondary education by the total female enrolment of lower secondary education and multiplying the result by 100.

UIS.T.23.GPV.name: Teaching staff in total secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. General programmes. Total
UIS.T.23.GPV.sourceNote: Teaching staff in total secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. General programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in general programmes in public and private secondary education institutions (ISCED 2 and 3). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

HH.DHS.SCR.Q3.name: DHS: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 3
HH.DHS.SCR.Q3.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 3 is the total number of quintile 3 students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of quintile 3 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 3 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

UIS.NIR.1.GPI.name: Gender parity index for net intake rate.  Primary.
UIS.NIR.1.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for net intake rate. Primary is the ratio of female net intake rate for primary to the male net intake rate for primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

UIS.E.23.AgI23.M.name: Pupils of the official school age.  Secondary.  Male
UIS.E.23.AgI23.M.sourceNote: Pupils of the official school age. Secondary. Male is the total number of male secondary school students who are of the official secondary school age (ISCED 2 & 3). NOTE: These values are not ‘capped’ i.e. the values are not necessarily the numerators used to calculate the net enrolment rates (for cases that are capped). To obtain the numerator for the NER, you can simply multiply the SAP of a relevant level by its corresponding NER.

UIS.AFR.GTCTR.1.T.name: Africa Dataset: Ratio of teacher training graduates to teachers in service. Primary. Public and private. Total
UIS.AFR.GTCTR.1.T.sourceNote: Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

HH.MICS.YRS.15UP.GIN.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.YRS.15UP.GIN.name: MICS: Gini coefficient of average years of schooling. Age 15+
HH.MICS.YRS.15UP.GIN.sourceNote: Gini coefficient of average years of schooling. Age 15+ measures the degree of inequality in years of schooling in a society. It is calculated similarly to the Gini coefficient of income or wealth. Results range from 0 to 100 with 0 indicating perfect equality and 100 indicating perfect inequality.

BAR.PRM.SCHL.5559.FE.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.PRM.SCHL.5559.FE.name: average years of primary schooling, 55-59, female
BAR.PRM.SCHL.5559.FE.sourceNote: Average years of primary schooling, 55-59, female is the average years of primary education completed among females age 55-59.

BAR.TER.SCHL.3034.name: average years of tertiary schooling, 30-34, total
BAR.TER.SCHL.3034.sourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 30-34, total is the average years of tertiary education completed among people age 30-34.

MYS.MEA.YSCH.1564.MA.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 15-64, male is the mean years of schooling of the male population age 15-64
