MYS.MEA.YSCH.1564.MF.name: mean years of schooling, 15-64, total
MYS.MEA.YSCH.1564.MF.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 15-64, total is the mean years of schooling of the population age 15-64

SE.PRM.PRIV.ZS.name: School enrollment, primary, private (% of total primary)
SE.PRM.PRIV.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Primary is the enrolment in private primary schools expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in primary schools. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.

BAR.SEC.CMPT.1519.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of population age 15-19 with secondary schooling. Completed Secondary

MYS.PROP.7579.NED.MA.name: proportion, 75-79, male, no education
MYS.PROP.7579.NED.MA.sourceNote: Proportion, 75-79, male, no education is the proportion of the male population age 75-79 with no education.

MYS.PROP.65UP.TER.FE.name: proportion, 65+, female, tertiary
MYS.PROP.65UP.TER.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 65+, female, tertiary is the proportion of the female population over age 65 with tertiary education.

HH.MICS.PCR.Q4.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.PCR.Q4.name: MICS: Primary completion rate. Quintile 4
HH.MICS.PCR.Q4.sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Quintile 4 is the total number of quintile 4 students of any age in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of quintile 4 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 4 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of primary school.

HH.MICS.PCR.Q5.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.PCR.Q5.name: MICS: Primary completion rate. Quintile 5
HH.MICS.PCR.Q5.sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Quintile 5 is the total number of quintile 5 students of any age in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of quintile 5 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 5 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of primary school.

HH.MICS.PCR.Q2.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.PCR.Q2.name: MICS: Primary completion rate. Quintile 2
HH.MICS.PCR.Q2.sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Quintile 2 is the total number of quintile 2 students of any age in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of quintile 2 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 2 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of primary school.

HH.MICS.PCR.Q3.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.PCR.Q3.name: MICS: Primary completion rate. Quintile 3
HH.MICS.PCR.Q3.sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Quintile 3 is the total number of quintile 3 students of any age in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of quintile 3 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 3 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of primary school.

HH.MICS.PCR.Q1.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.PCR.Q1.name: MICS: Primary completion rate. Quintile 1
HH.MICS.PCR.Q1.sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Quintile 1 is the total number of quintile 1 students of any age in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of quintile 1 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 1 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of primary school.

SE.SEC.DURS.UP.name: Duration of education, upper secondary
SE.SEC.DURS.UP.sourceNote: Duration of 3A upper secondary is the number of grades (years) in 3A upper secondary education.

MYS.POP.6569.NED.MA.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.6569.NED.MA.name: population in thousand, 65-69, male, no education
MYS.POP.6569.NED.MA.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 65-69, male, no education is the total number of males age 65-69 (in thousands) with no education.

UIS.FOSEP.56.F400.name: Percentage of tertiary enrolments (ISCED 5 and 6) in science
UIS.FOSEP.56.F400.sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary enrolments (ISCED 5 and 6) in science is the percentage of all tertiary students who are enrolled in science programmes.

MYS.POP.6569.NED.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.6569.NED.MF.name: population in thousand, 65-69, total, no education
MYS.POP.6569.NED.MF.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 65-69, total, no education is the total number of people age 65-69 (in thousands) with no education.

HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q3.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q3.name: DHS: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 3
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q3.sourceNote: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 3 is the number of new quintile 3 pupils attending the first grade of primary education who are of the official primary school entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the quintile 3 population of official entrance age to primary education.

HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q2.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q2.name: DHS: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 2
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q2.sourceNote: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 2 is the number of new quintile 2 pupils attending the first grade of primary education who are of the official primary school entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the quintile 2 population of official entrance age to primary education.

HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q1.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q1.name: DHS: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 1
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q1.sourceNote: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 1 is the number of new quintile 1 pupils attending the first grade of primary education who are of the official primary school entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the quintile 1 population of official entrance age to primary education.

UIS.XCURP.3.name: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Upper secondary
UIS.XCURP.3.sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Upper secondary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to upper secondary education.

SE.PRM.EPCR.FE.ZS.name: Expected primary completion rate, female (% of population at theoretical entrance age)
SE.PRM.EPCR.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Expected primary completion rate. Female is the total number of new female entrants to the first grade of primary in a given year, regardless of age, who are expected to reach the last grade of primary education, regardless of repetition, expressed as a percentage of the female population at the official entrance age to primary education in the same year. It is calculated by multiplying the gross intake ratio to the first grade of primary education by the survival rate to the last grade of primary. This indicator is also known as "Expected gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary. Female."

HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q5.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q5.name: DHS: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 5
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q5.sourceNote: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 5 is the number of new quintile 5 pupils attending the first grade of primary education who are of the official primary school entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the quintile 5 population of official entrance age to primary education.

HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q4.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q4.name: DHS: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 4
HH.DHS.NIR.1.Q4.sourceNote: Net intake rate for the first grade of primary education. Quintile 4 is the number of new quintile 4 pupils attending the first grade of primary education who are of the official primary school entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the quintile 4 population of official entrance age to primary education.

UIS.SR.2.GPV.GLAST.CP.T.name: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Total
UIS.SR.2.GPV.GLAST.CP.T.sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of lower secondary (General programmes). Total is the share of children enrolled in the first grade of secondary school who eventually reach the last grade of secondary school, regardless of repetition. To calculate this indicator, divide the total number of pupils in the last grade of secondary education by the number of pupils who originally enrolled in the first grade of secondary education, and multiply the result by 100. The survival rate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.

SE.PRM.DURS.name: Primary education, duration (years)
SE.PRM.DURS.sourceNote: Duration of primary is the number of grades (years) in primary education.

MYS.PROP.5054.PRI.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.5054.PRI.FE.name: proportion, 50-54, female, primary
MYS.PROP.5054.PRI.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 50-54, female, primary is the proportion of the female population age 50-54 with primary education.

SP.POP.AG12.TO.UN.name: Population, aged 12, total
SP.POP.AG12.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 12, total refers to the total population at the specified age.

SL.TLF.TOTL.IN.sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.
SL.TLF.TOTL.IN.name: Labor force, total
SL.TLF.TOTL.IN.sourceNote: Total labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization definition of the economically active population: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.

SE.TER.GRAD.EN.ZS.name: Graduates in engineering, manufacturing and construction (% of total graduates, tertiary)
SE.TER.GRAD.EN.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in engineering, manufacturing and construction is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied engineering, manufacturing and construction.

SE.PRM.UNER.sourceNote: Out-of-school children of primary school age. Total is the total number of primary-school-age children who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary schools.

UIS.E.0.Pu.F.sourceNote: Enrolment in pre-primary. Public. All programmes. Female is the total number of female students enrolled in public pre-primary education institutions.

SE.TER.ENRR.FE.sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5 and 6). Female is the total female enrollment in tertiary education (ISCED 5 and 6), regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total female population of the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving.

Tertiary is the enrolment in private tertiary institutions expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in tertiary institutions. SE.PRM.CMPL.ZS.sourceNote: Gross primary graduation ratio. Total is the total number of graduates from the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population at the theoretical graduation age. NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD.sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.
NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD.name: GDP per capita, PPP (current international $)
NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD.sourceNote: GDP per capita based on purchasing power parity (PPP). PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in current international dollars based on the 2011 ICP round.

LO.TIMSS.MAT4.INT.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study
LO.TIMSS.MAT4.INT.name: TIMSS: Fourth grade students reaching the intermediate international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%)
LO.TIMSS.MAT4.INT.sourceNote: TIMSS: Fourth grade students reaching the intermediate international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%) is the share of 4th grade students scoring at least 475 on the mathematics assessment. Students at this benchmark can apply basic mathematical knowledge in straightforward situations. Students at this level demonstrate an understanding of whole numbers and some understanding of fractions. Students can visualize three-dimensional shapes from two-dimensional representations. They can interpret bar graphs, pictographs, and tables to solve simple problems.

MYS.POP.2529.PRI.FE.name: population in thousand, 25 - 29, female, primary
MYS.POP.2529.PRI.FE.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 25-29, female, primary is the total number of females age 25-29 (in thousands) with primary education.

LO.TIMSS.SCI8.HI.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study
LO.TIMSS.SCI8.HI.name: TIMSS: Eighth grade students reaching the high international benchmark of science achievement (%)
LO.TIMSS.SCI8.HI.sourceNote: TIMSS: Eighth grade students reaching the high international benchmark of science achievement (%) is the share of 8th grade students scoring at least 550 on the science assessment. Students at this benchmark can demonstrate understanding of concepts related to science cycles, systems, and principles. They demonstrate understanding of aspects of human biology, and of the characteristics, classification, and life processes of organisms. Students communicate understanding of processes and relationships in ecosystems. They show an understanding of the classification and compositions of matter and chemical and physical properties and changes. They apply knowledge to situations related to light and sound and demonstrate basic knowledge of heat and temperature, forces and motion, and electrical circuits and magnets. Students demonstrate an understanding of the solar system and of Earth’s processes, physical features, and resources. They demonstrate some scientific inquiry skills. They also combine and interpret information from various types of diagrams, contour maps, graphs, and tables; select relevant information, analyze, and draw conclusions; and provide short explanations conveying scientific knowledge.

HH.DHS.OOST.X.F.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.X.F.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school. Female
HH.DHS.OOST.X.F.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school. Female is the percentage of female out-of-school primary-school-age children who have never attended school and are not likely to enter school in the future. Since no survey can say definitively that a school-age person will never attend school, this is a probabilistic indicator. The indicator is based on UNESCO’s methodology, which estimates the proportion of children who will never attend school as the proportion of out of school for the age group with the lowest proportion of out-of-school children. This methodology assumes no dropout before the age at which enrolment rates peak, and no late entry after the age with peak enrolment.

UIS.TRANRA.23.GPV.M.sourceNote: Effective transition rate from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes (%). Male shows the real transition from primary to secondary regardless of repetition. This indicator better reflects situations in which pupils repeat the last grade of primary but eventually make the transition to secondary. It is defined for a given year as the number of new male entrants to the first grade of secondary in the following year expressed as a percentage of the male students enrolled in the last grade of primary education in the given year who do not repeat that grade the following year.

HH.MICS.OOS.1.Q5.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.OOS.1.Q5.name: MICS: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Quintile 5
HH.MICS.OOS.1.Q5.sourceNote: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Quintile 5 is the number of quintile 5 children in the official primary school age range who are not attending primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of quintile 5 children of the official primary school age range. By definition, children in the official primary-age range, who are attending pre-primary education, are considered out-of-school. The sum of the net primary attendance rate and the proportion out of school do not add to 100 percent because the net primary attendance rate does not count students who are in secondary.

LO.TIMSS.MAT8.INT.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study
LO.TIMSS.MAT8.INT.name: TIMSS: Eighth grade students reaching the intermediate international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%)
LO.TIMSS.MAT8.INT.sourceNote: TIMSS: Eighth grade students reaching the intermediate international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%) is the share of 8th grade students scoring at least 475 on the mathematics assessment. Students at this benchmark can apply basic mathematical knowledge in a variety of situations. Students can solve problems involving decimals, fractions, proportions, and percentages. They understand simple algebraic relationships. Students can relate a two-dimensional drawing to a three-dimensional object. They can read, interpret, and construct graphs and tables. They recognize basic notions of likelihood.

UIS.SLE.0.M.name: School life expectancy (years).  Pre-primary.  Male
UIS.SLE.0.M.sourceNote: School life expectancy (years). Pre-primary. Male is the total number of years of schooling which a child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, assuming that the probability of his or her being enrolled in school at any particular age is equal to the current enrollment ratio for that age. For a child of a certain age a, the school life expectancy is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the levels of education specified. The part of the enrolment that is not distributed by age is divided by the school-age population for the level of education they are enrolled in, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education. The result is then added to the sum of the age-specific enrolment rates. The expected number of years does not necessarily coincide with the expected number of grades of education completed because of repetition.

UIS.SLE.0.F.name: School life expectancy (years).  Pre-primary.  Female

NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.sourceOrganization: World Bank national accounts data, and OECD National Accounts data files.
NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.name: GDP (constant 2005 US$)
NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.sourceNote: GDP at purchaser's prices is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2005 U.S. dollars. Dollar figures for GDP are converted from domestic currencies using 2000 official exchange rates. For a few countries where the official exchange rate does not reflect the rate effectively applied to actual foreign exchange transactions, an alternative conversion factor is used.

LO.TIMSS.SCI4.HI.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study
LO.TIMSS.SCI4.HI.name: TIMSS: Fourth grade students reaching the high international benchmark of science achievement (%)
LO.TIMSS.SCI4.HI.sourceNote: TIMSS: Fourth grade students reaching the high international benchmark of science achievement (%) is the share of 4th grade students scoring at least 550 on the science assessment. Students reaching this benchmark can apply their knowledge and understanding of the sciences to explain phenomena in everyday and abstract contexts. Students demonstrate some understanding of plant and animal structure, life processes, life cycles, and reproduction. They also demonstrate some understanding of ecosystems and organisms' interactions with their environment, including understanding of human responses to outside conditions and activities. Students demonstrate understanding of some properties of matter, electricity and energy, and magnetic and gravitational forces and motion. They show some knowledge of the solar system, and of Earth’s physical characteristics, processes, and resources. Students demonstrate elementary knowledge and skills related to scientific inquiry. They compare, contrast, and make simple inferences, and provide brief descriptive responses combining knowledge of science concepts with information from both everyday and abstract contexts.

UIS.LR.AG65.GPI.name: Gender parity index for elderly literacy rate
UIS.LR.AG65.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for elderly literacy rate is the ratio of female elderly literacy rate to the male elderly literacy rate. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

UIS.AIR.1.Glast.GPI.name: Gender parity index for gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary
UIS.AIR.1.Glast.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for primary completion rate is the ratio of the female primary completion rate to the male primary completion rate. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females. The primary completion rate indicator is also referred to as gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary.

UIS.GER.1t6.M.name: Gross enrolment ratio.  All levels combined (except pre-primary).  Male
UIS.GER.1t6.M.sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. All levels combined (except pre-primary). Male is the total male enrollment in primary, secondary and tertiary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total male population of primary school age, secondary school age, and the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.

UIS.FTP.3.name: Percentage female teachers.  Upper secondary
UIS.FTP.3.sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Upper secondary is the number of female teachers at the upper secondary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the upper secondary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

UIS.NERT.1.GPI.name: Gender parity index for adjusted net enrolment rate.  Primary
UIS.NERT.1.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for adjusted net enrolment rate. Primary is the ratio of female adjusted net enrolment rate for primary to the male adjusted net enrolment rate for primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

LO.PIRLS.REA.HI.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Progress in International Reading Literacy Study (PIRLS)
LO.PIRLS.REA.HI.name: PIRLS: Fourth grade students reaching the high international benchmark in reading achievement (%)
LO.PIRLS.REA.HI.sourceNote: Fourth grade students reaching the high international benchmark in reading achievement (%) is the share of fourth grade students scoring at least 550 on the reading assessment. When reading Literary Texts, students at the high benchmarking level can A) Locate and distinguish significant actions and details embedded across the text, B) Make inferences to explain relationships between intentions, actions, events, and feelings, and give text-based support, C) Interpret and integrate story events and character actions and traits from different parts of the text, D) Evaluate the significance of events and actions across the entire story, and E) Recognize the use of some language features (e.g., metaphor, tone, imagery). When reading Informational Texts, students at this benchmarking level can: A) Locate and distinguish relevant information within a dense text or a complex table, B) Make inferences about logical connections to provide explanations and reasons, C) Integrate textual and visual information to interpret the relationship between ideas, and D) Evaluate content and textual elements to make a generalization. For further information on benchmarking levels, please visit the PIRLS website.

HH.MICS.OOST.L.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.OOST.L.name: MICS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry
HH.MICS.OOST.L.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry is defined as the proportion of out-of-school children who are currently out of school but are expected to enter the education system later than they should. It is calculated based on UNESCO's methodology as the proportion leftover from those estimated as never in school, expressed as a percent of the proportion out-of-school for children younger than the age with the highest attendance rate.

BAR.SEC.SCHL.2529.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.SEC.SCHL.2529.name: average years of secondary schooling, 25-29, total

SP.POP.AG20.MA.UN.name: Population, aged 20, male
SP.POP.AG20.MA.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 20, male refers to the male population at the specified age.

HH.MICS.OOST.X.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.OOST.X.name: MICS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school
HH.MICS.OOST.X.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Never in school is the percentage of out-of-school primary-school-age children who have never attended school and are not likely to enter school in the future. Since no survey can say definitively that a school-age person will never attend school, this is a probabilistic indicator. The indicator is based on UNESCO’s methodology, which estimates the proportion of children who will never attend school as the proportion of out of school for the age group with the lowest proportion of out-of-school children. This methodology assumes no dropout before the age at which enrolment rates peak, and no late entry after the age with peak enrolment.

SL.TLF.TERT.ZS.sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.
SL.TLF.TERT.ZS.name: Labor force with tertiary education (% of total)
SL.TLF.TERT.ZS.sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.

SP.POP.AG15.FE.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 15, female refers to the female population at the specified age.

Female is the total number of female graduates in tertiary ISCED 5A programmes (first degree) expressed as a percentage of the female population of the age where they theoretically finish the most common first degree programme in the given country.

MYS.MEA.YSCH.25UP.FE.name: mean years of schooling, 25+, female
MYS.MEA.YSCH.25UP.FE.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 25+, female is the mean years of schooling of the female population over age 25.

HH.DHS.PCR.Q3.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.PCR.Q3.name: DHS: Primary completion rate. Quintile 3
HH.DHS.PCR.Q3.sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Quintile 3 is the total number of quintile 3 students of any age in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of quintile 3 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 3 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of primary school.

SE.TER.ENRL.MA.name: Student enrollment, tertiary, male
SE.TER.ENRL.MA.sourceNote: Enrolment in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Male is the total number of male students enrolled at public and private tertiary education institutions.

NY.GNP.MKTP.CD.name: GNI (current US$)
NY.GNP.MKTP.CD.sourceNote: GNI (formerly GNP) is the sum of value added by all resident producers plus any product taxes (less subsidies) not included in the valuation of output plus net receipts of primary income (compensation of employees and property income) from abroad. Data are in current U.S. dollars.

UIS.E.56.F500.F.name: Enrolment in engineering, manufacturing and construction. Tertiary.  Female
UIS.E.56.F500.F.sourceNote: Enrolment in engineering, manufacturing and construction. Tertiary. Female is the total number of females enrolled in tertiary engineering, manufacturing and construction programs.

SE.XPD.TCHR.XC.ZS.sourceNote: Educational expenditure on teachers salaries as a % of current education expenditures on public institutions. All Levels is spending on teacher salaries expressed as a percentage of the total current expenditures on education for all educational levels.

MYS.MEA.YSCH.65UP.MA.name: mean years of schooling, 65+, male
MYS.MEA.YSCH.65UP.MA.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 65+, male is the mean years of schooling of the male population over age 65.

MYS.MEA.YSCH.65UP.MF.name: mean years of schooling, 65+, total
MYS.MEA.YSCH.65UP.MF.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 65+, total is the mean years of schooling of the population over age 65.

UIS.LP.AG15T99.F.sourceNote: Adult illiterate population. Female is the total number of females over age 15 who cannot both read and write with understanding a short simple statement on their everyday life.

UIS.G.56.F400.dcount.F.name: Graduates in science. Tertiary. Female
UIS.G.56.F400.dcount.F.sourceNote: Graduates in science. Tertiary. Female is the total number of female tertiary graduates from science programs.

UIS.GER.1t6.GPI.name: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio.  All levels combined (except pre-primary)
UIS.GER.1t6.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for gross enrolment ratio. All levels combined (except pre-primary) is the ratio of female gross enrolment ratio for all levels combined (except pre-primary) to the male value for the same indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

SP.POP.0713.TO.UN.name: Population, aged 7-13, total
SP.POP.0713.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 7-13, total is the total population age 7-13.

MYS.POP.3539.TER.MF.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 35-39, total, tertiary is the total number of people age 35-39 (in thousands) with tertiary education.

MYS.POP.3539.TER.MA.name: population in thousand, 35-39, male, tertiary
MYS.POP.3539.TER.MA.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 35-39, male, tertiary is the total number of males age 35-39 (in thousands) with tertiary education.

HH.DHS.OOST.L.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.L.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry
HH.DHS.OOST.L.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry is defined as the proportion of out-of-school children who are currently out of school but are expected to enter the education system later than they should. It is calculated based on UNESCO's methodology as the proportion leftover from those estimated as never in school, expressed as a percent of the proportion out-of-school for children younger than the age with the highest attendance rate.

BAR.SEC.CMPT.75UP.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

HH.MICS.SCR.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.SCR.name: MICS: Secondary completion rate
HH.MICS.SCR.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate is the total number of students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

SL.TLF.SECO.ZS.sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.
SL.TLF.SECO.ZS.name: Labor force with secondary education (% of total)
SL.TLF.SECO.ZS.sourceNote: Labor force with secondary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a secondary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.

SP.POP.0509.FE.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 5-9, female is the total number of females age 5-9.

BAR.NOED.2529.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of female population age 25-29 with no education

LO.PISA.SCI.name: PISA:Mean performance on the science scale
LO.PISA.SCI.sourceNote: PISA: Mean performance on the science scale is the average score of 15-year-old students on science literacy scale.

UIS.SLE.1t6.GPI.name: Gender parity index for school life expectancy.  Primary to tertiary.
UIS.SLE.1t6.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for school life expectancy. Primary to tertiary is the ratio of female school life expectancy (primary to tertiary) to the male school life expectancy (primary to tertiary). It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

UIS.GTVP.2.V.sourceNote: Technical/vocational enrolment in lower secondary (ISCED 2) as % of total lower secondary enrolment (ISCED 2) is the percentage of all lower secondary students enrolled in technical/vocational education programs including teacher training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of students who are enrolled in lower secondary education.

UIS.R.23.GPV.G10.name: Repeaters in secondary. Grade 10. Total
UIS.R.23.GPV.G10.sourceNote: Repeaters in secondary. Grade 10. Total is the number of pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade for a second (or further) year.

SE.SEC.TCHR.name: Secondary education, teachers
SE.SEC.TCHR.sourceNote: Teaching staff in total secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in public and private secondary education institutions (ISCED 2 and 3). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

UIS.E.23.PR.name: Enrolment in total secondary. Private
UIS.E.23.PR.sourceNote: Enrolment in total secondary. Private is the total student enrolment in private secondary educational institutions.

SL.TLF.PRIM.MA.ZS.sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.
SL.TLF.PRIM.MA.ZS.name: Labor force with primary education, male (% of male labor force)
SL.TLF.PRIM.MA.ZS.sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.

SE.PRE.PRIV.ZS.name: Percentage of private enrolment.  Pre-primary.
SE.PRE.PRIV.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Pre-primary is the enrolment in private pre-primary schools expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in pre-primary schools. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.

UIS.TRANRA.23.GPV.GPI.name: Gender parity index for effective transition rate. Primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes
UIS.TRANRA.23.GPV.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for effective transition rate. Primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2). General programmes is the ratio of the female effective transition rate to the male value for the same indicator. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

UIS.E.1.AgI1.sourceNote: Pupils of the official school age. Primary. Total is the total number of primary school students who are of the official primary school age. NOTE: These values are not ‘capped’ i.e. the values are not necessarily the numerators used to calculate the net enrolment rates (for cases that are capped). To obtain the numerator for the NER, you can simply multiply the SAP of a relevant level by its corresponding NER.

LO.PASEC.FRE5.MA.sourceNote: PASEC: Mean performance on the French language scale (100 points) for 5th grade students, male is the average score on the 100 point French language scale for male 5th grade students. Note: Average differences are only significant between males and females in Benin, Burkina Faso, and Burundi. Since comparison is suggested by giving average scores for males/females, please take into account that these are only raw effects of gender. PASEC uses econometric models to validate the effect of gender in achievement.

UIS.XGNP.FSGOV.FNCUR.FFD.sourceNote: Current expenditure on education as % of GNI is the total public current education expenditure expressed as a percentage of the Gross National Income (GNI) in a given financial year. GNI is also referred to as Gross National Product (GNP).

UIS.T.3.F.name: Teaching staff in upper secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female
UIS.T.3.F.sourceNote: Teaching staff in upper secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in public and private upper secondary education institutions (ISCED 3). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

SE.TER.ENRL.sourceNote: Enrolment in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Total is the total number of students enrolled at public and private tertiary education institutions.

SE.TER.ENRR.name: School enrollment, tertiary (% gross)
SE.TER.ENRR.sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5 and 6). Total is the total enrollment in tertiary education (ISCED 5 and 6), regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total population of the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving.

SE.PRM.CMPL.MA.ZS.name: Gross primary graduation ratio, male
SE.PRM.CMPL.MA.ZS.sourceNote: Gross primary graduation ratio. Male is the number of male graduates from the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the male population at the theoretical graduation age. The ratio can exceed 100% due to over-aged and under-aged children who enter primary school for the first time early/late or/and repeat a grade.

SE.TER.GRAD.FE.OT.ZS.name: Female share of graduates in unknown or unspecified fields (%, tertiary)
SE.TER.GRAD.FE.OT.ZS.sourceNote: Female share of graduates in unknown or unspecified fields (%, tertiary)

UIS.AFR.TRNTP.2.PU.T.sourceNote: Share of newly recruited public lower secondary school teachers who have been trained. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

UIS.REPP.1.G5.F.name: Percentage of repeaters in primary. Grade 5. Female
UIS.REPP.1.G5.F.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in primary. Grade 5. Female is the total number of female pupils in the specified grade who are enrolled in the same grade as in a previous year, expressed as a percentage of the total female enrollment in the specified grade. It is calculated by dividing the number of female pupils repeating a given grade in a given school year by the number of female pupils enrolled in the same grade in the same school year and multiplying by 100.

UIS.REPP.1.GPI.name: Gender parity index for % repeaters. All grades. Primary
UIS.REPP.1.GPI.sourceNote: Gender parity index for % repeaters. All grades. Primary is the ratio of female percentage of repeaters in primary to the male percentage of repeaters in primary. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.

UIS.AFR.TRNTP.2.PU.M.sourceNote: Share of newly recruited male public lower secondary school teachers who have been trained. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

It is calculated by dividing the number of female pupils repeating a given grade in a given school year by the number of female pupils enrolled in the same grade in the same school year and multiplying by 100.

UIS.REPP.1.G5.M.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in primary. Grade 5. MYS.MEA.YSCH.4549.MF.name: mean years of schooling, 45-49, total
MYS.MEA.YSCH.4549.MF.sourceNote: Mean years of schooling, 45-49, total is the mean years of schooling of the population age 45-49.

UIS.SLE.0.name: School life expectancy (years).  Pre-primary.  Total
UIS.SLE.0.sourceNote: School life expectancy (years). Pre-primary. Total is the total number of years of schooling which a child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, assuming that the probability of his or her being enrolled in school at any particular age is equal to the current enrollment ratio for that age. For a child of a certain age a, the school life expectancy is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the levels of education specified. The part of the enrolment that is not distributed by age is divided by the school-age population for the level of education they are enrolled in, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education. The result is then added to the sum of the age-specific enrolment rates. The expected number of years does not necessarily coincide with the expected number of grades of education completed because of repetition.

UIS.GGR.2.GPV.F.sourceNote: Gross lower secondary graduation ratio. General programmes. LO.TIMSS.MAT4.HI.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study
LO.TIMSS.MAT4.HI.name: TIMSS: Fourth grade students reaching the high international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%)
LO.TIMSS.MAT4.HI.sourceNote: TIMSS: Fourth grade students reaching the high international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%) is the share of 4th grade students scoring at least 550 on the mathematics assessment. Students at this benchmark can apply their knowledge and understanding to solve problems. Students can solve word problems involving operations with whole numbers. They can use division in a variety of problem situations. They can use their understanding of place value to solve problems. Students can extend patterns to find a later specified term. Students demonstrate understanding of line symmetry and geometric properties. Students can interpret and use data in tables and graphs to solve problems. They can use information in pictographs and tally charts to complete bar graphs.

UIS.ROFSPPT.1.sourceNote: Share of primary school-age children enrolled in pre-primary education (%). Total is total number of primary school age children who are enrolled in pre-primary education expressed as a percentage of the total primary school age population.

UIS.NIR.1.AGP1.name: Net intake rate. Primary. Over age (+1). Total
UIS.NIR.1.AGP1.sourceNote: Net intake rate. Primary. Over age (+1). Total is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education who are one year older than the official primary school-entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the primary school entrance age.

SP.POP.AG01.MA.UN.name: Population, aged  1, male
SP.POP.AG01.MA.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 1, male refers to the male population at the specified age.

SE.XPD.TOTL.PC.ZS.sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. All levels is the total public expenditure per student as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).

SP.POP.1116.MA.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 11-16, male is the total number of males age 11-16.

UIS.FOSEP.56.FUK.F.sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary enrolments (ISCED 5 and 6) in general and unspecified programmes is the percentage of all female tertiary students who are enrolled in general and unspecified programmes.

UIS.G.56.F800.dcount.name: Graduates in services. Tertiary. Total
UIS.G.56.F800.dcount.sourceNote: Graduates in services. Tertiary. Total is the total number of tertiary graduates from services programs.

SE.SEC.REPT.FE.ZS.name: Repeaters, secondary, female (% of female enrollment)
SE.SEC.REPT.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. All grades. Female is the number of female students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all female students enrolled in secondary school. It is calculated by dividing the sum of female repeaters in all grades of secondary education by the total female enrolment of secondary education and multiplying the result by 100.

HH.DHS.TR.12.Q3.sourceNote: Transition rate. Primary to Secondary. Quintile 3 is the proportion of quintile 3 pupils in the last grade of primary who transition to the first grade of secondary the following school year.

LO.SACMEQ.REA.sourceNote: SACMEQ: Mean performance on the mathematics scale is the mean mathematics score for 6th grade students. Mean scores are on SACMEQ scales for reading, which have averages of 500 and standard deviations of 100.

SE.XPD.CUR.TOTL.ZS.sourceNote: Public current expenditure on education as % of total public education expenditure is the recurrent public education expenditure expressed as a percentage of total public expenditure on education (current and capital) in a given financial year.

HH.DHS.OOST.L.R.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.L.R.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry. Rural
HH.DHS.OOST.L.R.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Late entry. Rural is defined as the proportion of rural out-of-school children who are currently out of school but are expected to enter the education system later than they should. It is calculated based on UNESCO's methodology as the proportion leftover from those estimated as never in school, expressed as a percent of the proportion out-of-school for children younger than the age with the highest attendance rate.

SE.PRM.TCHR.FE.ZS.name: Primary education, teachers (% female)
SE.PRM.TCHR.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Primary is the number of female teachers at the primary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the primary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

HH.MICS.YRS.1519.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.YRS.1519.name: MICS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19

SE.ADT.1524.LT.MA.ZS.sourceNote: Youth (15-24) literacy rate (%). Male is the number of males age 15 to 24 years who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement on their everyday life, divided by the male population in that age group. LO.PASEC.FRE5.HIG.FE.name: PASEC: 5th grade students above the Knowledge Base Rate on the French language scale (above 40% of answers correct) (%), female
LO.PASEC.FRE5.HIG.FE.sourceNote: Indicator is the share of female students who score above the Knowledge Base Rate, which is the proportion of pupils who achieve a minimum learning goal, based on the programs of the level selected, appropriate to the scale of the tests used.

SL.TLF.TERT.FE.ZS.sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.
SL.TLF.TERT.FE.ZS.name: Labor force with tertiary education, female (% of female labor force)
SL.TLF.TERT.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Labor force with tertiary education is the proportion of labor force that has a tertiary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.

BAR.PRM.ICMP.5054.FE.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

BAR.PRM.ICMP.5054.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of female population age 50-54 with primary schooling. Total (Incomplete and Completed Primary)

SP.POP.TOTL.MA.ZS.sourceOrganization: The United Nations Population Division's World Population Prospects.
SP.POP.TOTL.MA.ZS.name: Population, male (% of total)
SP.POP.TOTL.MA.ZS.sourceNote: Population, male (% of total) is the percentage of the population that is male.

LO.LLECE.REA3.LOW.FE.sourceOrganization: Latin American Laboratory for Assessment of the Quality of Education (LLECE)
LO.LLECE.REA3.LOW.FE.name: LLECE: 3rd grade students at the lowest level of proficiency on the reading scale (%), female
LO.LLECE.REA3.LOW.FE.sourceNote: 3rd grade students at the lowest level of proficiency on the reading scale (%), female

MYS.POP.5054.PRI.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.5054.PRI.FE.name: population in thousand, 50-54, female, primary
MYS.POP.5054.PRI.FE.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 50-54, female, primary is the total number of females age 50-54 (in thousands) with primary education.

UIS.T.4.V.name: Teaching staff in post-secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. Technical/vocational programmes. Total
UIS.T.4.V.sourceNote: Teaching staff in post-secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. Technical/vocational programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in technical/vocational programmes in public and private post-secondary education institutions (ISCED 4). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.

BAR.SEC.SCHL.2024.FE.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.SEC.SCHL.2024.FE.name: average years of secondary schooling, 20-24, female
BAR.SEC.SCHL.2024.FE.sourceNote: Average years of secondary schooling, 20-24, female is the average years of secondary education completed among females age 20-24.

SE.PRM.CMPT.ZS.name: Primary completion rate, total (% of relevant age group)
SE.PRM.CMPT.ZS.sourceNote: Primary completion rate is measured as the gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary education. It is calculated by taking the total number of students in the last grade of primary school, minus the number of repeaters in that grade, divided by the total number of children of official graduation age.

MYS.POP.3539.SEC.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.3539.SEC.MF.name: population in thousand, 35-39, total, secondary
MYS.POP.3539.SEC.MF.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 35-39, total, secondary is the total number of people age 35-39 (in thousands) with secondary education.

MYS.POP.3539.SEC.MA.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.3539.SEC.MA.name: population in thousand, 35-39, male, secondary
MYS.POP.3539.SEC.MA.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 35-39, male, secondary is the total number of males age 35-39 (in thousands) with secondary education.

UIS.ECDP.1.M.name: Percentage of new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience.  Male
UIS.ECDP.1.M.sourceNote: Percentage of new entrants to primary education with ECCE experience. Male is the number of new male entrants to primary grade 1 who have attended some form of organized early childhood care and education (ECCE) program for the equivalent of at least 200 hours, expressed as a percentage of total number of new male entrants to primary grade 1.

UIS.AFR.SCHBSP.1.PU.WPOWAT.name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools with potable water. Primary. Public
UIS.AFR.SCHBSP.1.PU.WPOWAT.sourceNote: Share of primary schools without a drinking water facility or water delivery point that is designed to protect water from external contamination, particularly of fecal origin. Examples of potable drinking water facilities include pipe-borne water, protected well, borehole, protected spring water and rainwater. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

UIS.E.3.PU.name: Enrolment in upper secondary. Public. All programmes. Total
UIS.E.3.PU.sourceNote: Enrolment in upper secondary. Public. All programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in public upper secondary education institutions.

MYS.PROP.15UP.PRI.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.15UP.PRI.FE.name: proportion, 15+, female, primary
MYS.PROP.15UP.PRI.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 15+, female, primary is the proportion of the female population over age 15 with primary education.

UIS.E.4.name: Enrolment in post-secondary non tertiary. Public and private. All programmes. Total
UIS.E.4.sourceNote: Enrolment in post-secondary non tertiary. Public and private. All programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in public and private post-secondary/non-tertiary education institutions.

UIS.E.3.name: Enrolment in upper secondary. Public and private. All programmes. Total
UIS.E.3.sourceNote: Enrolment in upper secondary. Public and private. All programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in public and private upper secondary education institutions.

UIS.E.2.name: Enrolment in lower secondary. Public and private. All programmes. Total
UIS.E.2.sourceNote: Enrolment in lower secondary. Public and private. All programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in public and private lower secondary education institutions.

SP.POP.AG13.FE.UN.name: Population, aged 13, female
SP.POP.AG13.FE.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 13, female refers to the female population at the specified age.

SE.SEC.ENRL.FE.VO.ZS.name: Vocational and Technical enrollment (% of total secondary enrollment), female
SE.SEC.ENRL.FE.VO.ZS.sourceNote: Technical/vocational enrolment in secondary (ISCED 2 and 3) as % of total secondary enrolment (ISCED 2 and 3), female is the percentage of all female lower and upper secondary students enrolled in technical/vocational education programs including teacher training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of female students who are enrolled in lower and upper secondary education.

BAR.NOED.6064.FE.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.NOED.6064.FE.ZS.name: Barro-Lee: Percentage of female population age 60-64 with no education
BAR.NOED.6064.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of female population age 60-64 with no education

BAR.TER.CMPT.7074.FE.ZS.name: Barro-Lee: Percentage of female population age 70-74 with tertiary schooling. Completed Tertiary
BAR.TER.CMPT.7074.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of female population age 70-74 with tertiary schooling. Completed Tertiary

UIS.UAPP.1.name: Under-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Total
UIS.UAPP.1.sourceNote: Under-age enrolment ratio. Primary. Total is the percentage of the primary school age population (ISCED 1) that is under the official primary school age.

MYS.POP.80UP.TER.MF.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.80UP.TER.MF.name: population in thousand, 80+, total, tertiary
MYS.POP.80UP.TER.MF.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 80+, total, tertiary is the total number of people over age 80 (in thousands) with tertiary education.

BAR.SEC.ICMP.7074.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.SEC.ICMP.7074.ZS.name: Barro-Lee: Percentage of population age 70-74 with secondary schooling. Total (Incomplete and Completed Secondary)
BAR.SEC.ICMP.7074.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of population age 70-74 with secondary schooling. Total (Incomplete and Completed Secondary)

MYS.POP.80UP.TER.MA.name: population in thousand, 80+, male, tertiary
MYS.POP.80UP.TER.MA.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 80+, male, tertiary is the total number of males over age 80 (in thousands) with tertiary education.

BAR.PRM.SCHL.6569.FE.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.PRM.SCHL.6569.FE.name: average years of primary schooling, 65-69, female
BAR.PRM.SCHL.6569.FE.sourceNote: Average years of primary schooling, 65-69, female is the average years of primary education completed among females age 65-69.

SP.POP.0510.FE.UN.name: Population, aged 5-10, female
SP.POP.0510.FE.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 5-10, female is the total number of females age 5-10.

LO.TIMSS.MAT8.HI.sourceOrganization: International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement (IEA)'s Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study
LO.TIMSS.MAT8.HI.name: TIMSS: Eighth grade students reaching the high international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%)
LO.TIMSS.MAT8.HI.sourceNote: TIMSS: Eighth grade students reaching the high international benchmark of mathematics achievement (%) is the share of 8th grade students scoring at least 550 on the mathematics assessment. Students at this benchmark can apply their understanding and knowledge in a variety of relatively complex situations. Students can use information from several sources to solve problems involving different types of numbers and operations. Students can relate fractions, decimals, and percents to each other. Students at this level show basic procedural knowledge related to algebraic expressions. They can use properties of lines, angles, triangles, rectangles, and rectangular prisms to solve problems. They can analyze data in a variety of graphs.

BAR.TER.ICMP.4044.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.TER.ICMP.4044.ZS.name: Barro-Lee: Percentage of population age 40-44 with tertiary schooling. Total (Incomplete and Completed Tertiary)
BAR.TER.ICMP.4044.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of population age 40-44 with tertiary schooling. Total (Incomplete and Completed Tertiary)

SP.POP.AG04.TO.UN.name: Population, aged  4, total
SP.POP.AG04.TO.UN.sourceNote: Population, age 4, total refers to the total population at the specified age.

UIS.SLE.56.name: School life expectancy (years).  Tertiary.  Total
UIS.SLE.56.sourceNote: School life expectancy (years). Tertiary. Total is the total number of years of schooling which a child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, assuming that the probability of his or her being enrolled in school at any particular age is equal to the current enrollment ratio for that age. For a child of a certain age a, the school life expectancy is calculated as the sum of the age specific enrolment rates for the levels of education specified. The part of the enrolment that is not distributed by age is divided by the school-age population for the level of education they are enrolled in, and multiplied by the duration of that level of education. The result is then added to the sum of the age-specific enrolment rates. The expected number of years does not necessarily coincide with the expected number of grades of education completed because of repetition.

HH.DHS.NAR.1.R.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.NAR.1.R.name: DHS: Net attendance rate. Primary. Rural
HH.DHS.NAR.1.R.sourceNote: Net attendance rate. Primary. Rural is the proportion of rural children of the official primary school age who are attending primary school. The primary school age is based on the parameters of the educational system: starting age and duration of primary school.

NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.KD.sourceOrganization: World Bank, International Comparison Program database.
NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.KD.name: GDP, PPP (constant 2011 international $)
NY.GDP.MKTP.PP.KD.sourceNote: PPP GDP is gross domestic product converted to international dollars using purchasing power parity rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP as the U.S. dollar has in the United States. GDP is the sum of gross value added by all resident producers in the economy plus any product taxes and minus any subsidies not included in the value of the products. It is calculated without making deductions for depreciation of fabricated assets or for depletion and degradation of natural resources. Data are in constant 2011 international dollars.

HH.DHS.NAR.1.U.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.NAR.1.U.name: DHS: Net attendance rate. Primary. Urban
HH.DHS.NAR.1.U.sourceNote: Net attendance rate. Primary. Urban is the proportion of urban children of the official primary school age who are attending primary school. The primary school age is based on the parameters of the educational system: starting age and duration of primary school.

MYS.PROP.2024.SEC.FE.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.PROP.2024.SEC.FE.name: proportion, 20 - 24, female, secondary
MYS.PROP.2024.SEC.FE.sourceNote: Proportion, 20-24, female, secondary is the proportion of the female population age 20-24 with secondary education.

HH.DHS.NAR.1.F.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.NAR.1.F.name: DHS: Net attendance rate. Primary. Female
HH.DHS.NAR.1.F.sourceNote: Net attendance rate. Primary. Female is the proportion of female children of the official primary school age who are attending primary school. The primary school age is based on the parameters of the educational system: starting age and duration of primary school.

UIS.AFR.TATTRR.3.Pu.F.name: Africa Dataset: Teacher attrition rate. Upper secondary. Public. Female
UIS.AFR.TATTRR.3.Pu.F.sourceNote: Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

HH.DHS.NAR.1.M.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.NAR.1.M.name: DHS: Net attendance rate. Primary. Male
HH.DHS.NAR.1.M.sourceNote: Net attendance rate. Primary. Male is the proportion of male children of the official primary school age who are attending primary school. The primary school age is based on the parameters of the educational system: starting age and duration of primary school.

UIS.NIR.1.AGM1.M.name: Net intake rate. Primary. Under age (-1). Male
UIS.NIR.1.AGM1.M.sourceNote: Net intake rate. Primary. Under age (-1). Male is the number of new male entrants in the first grade of primary education who are one year younger than the official primary school-entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the male population of the primary school entrance age.

HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q1.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q1.name: MICS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 1
HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q1.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 1 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 1 population of the given age group.

HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q2.name: MICS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 2
HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q2.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 2 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 2 population of the given age group.

HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q3.name: MICS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 3
HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q3.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 3 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 3 population of the given age group.

HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q4.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q4.name: MICS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 4
HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q4.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 4 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 4 population of the given age group.

HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q5.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q5.name: MICS: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 5
HH.MICS.YRS.1519.Q5.sourceNote: Average years of schooling by age group. Age 15-19. Quintile 5 is the number of years of formal schooling received, on average, by the quintile 5 population of the given age group.

MYS.POP.80UP.NED.MF.name: population in thousand, 80+, total, no education
MYS.POP.80UP.NED.MF.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 80+, total, no education is the total number of people over age 80 (in thousands) with no education.

MYS.POP.80UP.NED.MA.sourceOrganization: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA)/Vienna Institute of Demography (VID)
MYS.POP.80UP.NED.MA.name: population in thousand, 80+, male, no education
MYS.POP.80UP.NED.MA.sourceNote: Population in thousand, 80+, male, no education is the total number of males over age 80 (in thousands) with no education.

HH.MICS.SCR.Q5.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.SCR.Q5.name: MICS: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 5
HH.MICS.SCR.Q5.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 5 is the total number of quintile 5 students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of quintile 5 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 5 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

HH.MICS.SCR.Q4.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.SCR.Q4.name: MICS: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 4
HH.MICS.SCR.Q4.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 4 is the total number of quintile 4 students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of quintile 4 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 4 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

HH.MICS.SCR.Q3.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.SCR.Q3.name: MICS: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 3
HH.MICS.SCR.Q3.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 3 is the total number of quintile 3 students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of quintile 3 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 3 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

HH.MICS.SCR.Q2.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.SCR.Q2.name: MICS: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 2
HH.MICS.SCR.Q2.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 2 is the total number of quintile 2 students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of quintile 2 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 2 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

HH.MICS.SCR.Q1.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.SCR.Q1.name: MICS: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 1
HH.MICS.SCR.Q1.sourceNote: Secondary completion rate. Quintile 1 is the total number of quintile 1 students of any age in last grade of secondary school, minus the number of quintile 1 repeaters in that grade, divided by the number of quintile 1 children of official graduation age. The completion rate can exceed 100 percent if there are many overage students in the last grade of secondary school.

HH.DHS.OOST.DO.M.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.M.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Male
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.M.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Male is the proportion of male out-of-school children who were enrolled in school and dropped out. It is calculated as the proportion of children not classified as never-in-school expressed as a percent of the proportion of out-of-school children older than the age with the highest attendance rate.

BAR.NOED.6569.FE.ZS.sourceOrganization: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/
BAR.NOED.6569.FE.ZS.name: Barro-Lee: Percentage of female population age 65-69 with no education
BAR.NOED.6569.FE.ZS.sourceNote: Percentage of female population age 65-69 with no education

HH.DHS.OOST.DO.F.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.F.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Female
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.F.sourceNote: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Female is the proportion of female out-of-school children who were enrolled in school and dropped out. It is calculated as the proportion of children not classified as never-in-school expressed as a percent of the proportion of out-of-school children older than the age with the highest attendance rate.

HH.MICS.OOS.1.Q4.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Multiple Cluster Indicator Survey (MICS) data
HH.MICS.OOS.1.Q4.name: MICS: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Quintile 4
HH.MICS.OOS.1.Q4.sourceNote: Proportion of out-of-school. Primary. Quintile 4 is the number of quintile 4 children in the official primary school age range who are not attending primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of quintile 4 children of the official primary school age range. By definition, children in the official primary-age range, who are attending pre-primary education, are considered out-of-school. The sum of the net primary attendance rate and the proportion out of school do not add to 100 percent because the net primary attendance rate does not count students who are in secondary.

SP.PRM.GRAD.TO.name: School age population. Primary. Last Grade. Total
SP.PRM.GRAD.TO.sourceNote: School age population. Primary. Last Grade. Total is the population of the age-group theoretically corresponding to the last grade of primary school as indicated by theoretical entrance age and duration.

HH.DHS.OOST.DO.U.sourceOrganization: Porta (2011) using Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) data
HH.DHS.OOST.DO.U.name: DHS: Typology of out-of-school children. Primary. Dropped out. Urban

It is calculated as the proportion of children not classified as never-in-school expressed as a percent of the proportion of out-of-school children older than the age with the highest attendance rate.
